From Wiktionary, the free dictionary

Asturian

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From clavu or from Late Latin clāvāre, from Latin clāvus.

Verb

[edit]

clavar (first-person singular indicative present clavo, past participle claváu)

  1. (transitive) to nail (employ a nail as a fastener)

Conjugation

[edit]
Conjugation of clavar
infinitive clavar
gerund clavando
past participle m claváu, f clavada, n clavao, m pl clavaos, f pl clavaes
person first singular
yo 		second singular
tu 		third singular
él/elli 		first plural
nosotros/nós 		second plural
vosotros/vós 		third plural
ellos
indicative present clavo claves clava clavamos claváis claven
imperfect clavaba clavabes clavaba clavábemos, clavábamos clavabeis, clavabais clavaben
preterite clavé clavasti, clavesti clavó clavemos clavastis, clavestis clavaron
pluperfect clavare, clavara clavares, clavaras clavare, clavara claváremos, claváramos clavareis, clavarais clavaren, clavaran
future clavaré clavarás clavará clavaremos clavaréis clavarán
conditional clavaría clavaríes clavaría clavaríemos, clavaríamos clavaríeis, clavaríais clavaríen
subjunctive present clave claves, clavas clave clavemos clavéis claven, clavan
imperfect clavare, clavara clavares, clavaras clavare, clavara claváremos, claváramos clavareis, clavarais clavaren, clavaran
imperative — clava — — clavái —

Related terms

[edit]
  • clavu

Catalan

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Inherited from Late Latin clāvāre (compare Occitan clavar, Spanish clavar, Portuguese cravar, French clouer, Italian chiavare), from Latin clāvus. Equivalent to, but not synchronically derivable from, clau (“[a] nail”) +‎ -ar.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): (Central) [kləˈβa]
  • IPA(key): (Balearic) [kləˈva]
  • IPA(key): (Valencia) [klaˈvaɾ]
  • Audio (Barcelona):(file)

Verb

[edit]

clavar (first-person singular present clavo, first-person singular preterite claví, past participle clavat)

  1. (transitive) to nail
  2. (transitive) to pin
  3. (transitive) to attach, stick
    Synonym: fixar

Conjugation

[edit]

Related terms

[edit]
  • clau

Further reading

[edit]
  • “clavar”, in Diccionari de la llengua catalana [Dictionary of the Catalan Language] (in Catalan), second edition, Institute of Catalan Studies [Catalan: Institut d'Estudis Catalans], April 2007
  • “clavar” in Diccionari català-valencià-balear, Antoni Maria Alcover and Francesc de Borja Moll, 1962.
  • “clavar”, in Gran Diccionari de la Llengua Catalana, Grup Enciclopèdia Catalana, 2025

Occitan

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

clau +‎ -ar. Clau reverts back to its Latin root clav, from clāvis (“key”). Alternatively (through Old Occitan [Term?]), from Late Latin clāvāre, from Latin clāvus.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • Audio (Béarn):(file)

Verb

[edit]

clavar

  1. to lock
  2. (figuratively) to lock; to close
  3. to nail

Conjugation

[edit]

Spanish

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From clavo or from Late Latin clāvāre, from Latin clāvus. Compare Portuguese cravar.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /klaˈbaɾ/ [klaˈβ̞aɾ]
  • Rhymes: -aɾ
  • Syllabification: cla‧var

Verb

[edit]

clavar (first-person singular present clavo, first-person singular preterite clavé, past participle clavado)

  1. to nail, to pin, to stick

Conjugation

[edit]
    Conjugation of clavar (See Appendix:Spanish verbs)
infinitive clavar
gerund clavando
past participle masculine feminine
singular clavado clavada
plural clavados clavadas
singular plural
1st person 2nd person 3rd person 1st person 2nd person 3rd person
indicative yo tú
vos 		él/ella/ello
usted 		nosotros
nosotras 		vosotros
vosotras 		ellos/ellas
ustedes
present clavo clavastú
clavásvos 		clava clavamos claváis clavan
imperfect clavaba clavabas clavaba clavábamos clavabais clavaban
preterite clavé clavaste clavó clavamos clavasteis clavaron

conditional clavaría clavarías clavaría clavaríamos clavaríais clavarían

vos 		él/ella/ello

vos 		usted nosotros
nosotras 		vosotros

affirmative clavatú
clavávos 		clave clavemos clavad claven
negative no claves no clave no clavemos no clavéis no claven

1Rare; now chiefly used in legal language.
2Argentine and Uruguayan voseo prefers the tuteo-form for the present subjunctive.
